div.head: Drawings from the Tour of 1833
div.p: Drawings that Ruskin made during the Tour of 1833—and possibly, some of them, after the familyʼs return home—are listed here in topographical order according to the tour itinerary. I am grateful to Stephen Wildman for the basis of this list. Several of the 1833 tour sketches can no longer be traced.

Omitted from this list are the drawings that Ruskin made as vignettes to illustrate Account of a Tour on the Continent, which occupied Ruskinʼs creative energy for about a year following the familyʼs return in September 1833 (see Date), and which are documented as part of ERMʼs edition of the “Account”. The tour sketches are distinct from the vignettes in style and other features, even though Ruskin based some of the vignettes on tour sketches, as explained in Account of a Tour on the Continent: Missing and Unidentified Drawings for the Composite‐Genre Illustrated Travelogue (MS IX) and Related 1833 Tour Sketches. The vignettes are not tour sketches, but imitations of how British readers consumed Continental scenery in context of British print culture of the 1830s. Nonetheless, the list may perpetuate some confusion in the catalogues of Ruskinʼs drawings between tour sketches and vignettes for the “Account”, since too little is known about some drawings that can no longer be traced. Some titles listed as tour sketches in the catalogues may in fact have been vignettes intended for use directly in the fair‐copy version of the “Account”, MS IX, but which became separated from the manuscript or were never permanently affixed to the manuscript. For bibliographical details, see again Missing and Unidentified Drawings for the Composite‐Genre Illustrated Travelogue (MS IX) and Related 1833 Tour Sketches.

Two 1833–34 drawings that cannot be located—Watch‐tower at Andernach, and The Jungfrau—are preserved in facsimile by photogravure. It is ironic that the originals vanished in a process of reproduction that, in W. G. Collingwoodʼs characterization, was driven by a desire for authenticity. According to his “Prefatory Notes on the Plates” in the 1891 edition of Ruskinʼs Poems, Collingwood along with the “publisher, engravers, and printers” were motivated by an “anxiety . . . that the plates should represent the original drawings as accurately as modern skill permits”. As a foil, Collingwood characterizes the “old standard art” of engraving used to illustrate Ruskinʼs earlier books as a “joint” project of designer and engraver, like “concerted music” performed by “players on different instruments”. An authentic solo performance by the designer was not reproducible on a mass scale; “it was never . . . [the artist and engraverʼs] intention to give the style and touch of the draughtsman, his separate individuality, his momentary mood, as shown in the very material and handling of the original sketch”. Now this authentic individuality had come within reach, it seemed, with the invention “of modern photographic engraving”, which Collingwood regards as an attempt “to reproduce the master, to facsimile the authentic document”. The means of reproduction aligns with Collingwoodʼs biographically oriented editorial aims: “this is what we want here in such pictures as rightly illustrate a collection of Poems written in Youth, in bygone historic times, recording a famous manʼs childhood and boyhood, his first impressions and fresh ideas of the world and of life”. Photographic engraving promises to supply “genuine records of the traditional precocity which we should like to verify: some true measure of the progress which we suspect, but cannnot otherwise trace, by which genius was developed. We want to see Ruskinʼs drawings, and not engraverʼs plates” (Poems [4o, 1891], 1:v).

In the 1891 Poems (large‐paper edition only, as the octavo edition offered no plates), the ȁPrefatory Note on the Plates” complements the “Preliminary Note on the Original MSS. of the Poems”, but the former was placed at the front of volume one, and the latter at its end, presumably because the physical witness of the photogravure plates offered the closest possible encounter with the actuality of Ruskinʼs youth. Comparatively, the edited and printed poems placed the material manuscripts at a step removed, intervened by the editor, although some compensation was afforded by photogravure reproduction of samples of Ruskinʼs early handwriting. Collingwood admits that “no reproduction can be quite the same thing as an original, if the original owe any of its interest to the more subtle artistic qualities of line and tone”. The benefit of photogravure, in Collingwoodʼs mind, lay in its “mechanical reproduction by a method which, clever and charming as it is, adds nothing to . . . [the sketchesʼ] cleverness and charm”, the mechanization assuring that what was conveyed was at least purely authentic, however deficient otherwise. At the same time, Collingwood notes that “Messrs. Walker and Boutallʼs photogravures” were “helped by Mr. George Allen”s retouching” (Poems [4o, 1891], 1:vi). From a twenty‐first century perspective, “photogravure was a hand process” incorporating the eighteenth‐century technique of aquatint; and “early attempts to print photographs in ink often included efforts to retain this capacity to manipulate the image” through “intrusions of handwork” (Benson, The Printed Picture, 236, 232).

In the list below, titles cited with quotation marks refer to captions that Ruskin wrote directly on the tour sketch. Titles that are not Ruskinʼs, or that cannot be definitely traced to him, are cited without quotation marks. Citations of Ruskin, Works refer, unless otherwise specified, to the “Catalogue of Ruskinʼs Drawings” compiled for the Library Edition (38:215–306); citations of Collingwood, Life and Work of John Ruskin, refer to the “Catalogue of Drawings by Mr. Ruskin (1829–1859)” (1:238–43); and citations of Collingwood, Ruskin Exhibition, refer to the catalogue of the Ruskin Exhibition, Coniston, 1900.
